TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in GPE . He is represented before the Court by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE

In DATE the applicant purchased PERSON , a house and garden in GPE , GPE , for GBP CARDINAL . At that time the property was in open countryside and according to the structure plan prepared pursuant to ORG DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) , no significant development was planned for the area . The value of properties in the GPE increased substantially , and by DATE PERSON was worth MONEY . On DATE , and again on DATE , the applicant was granted mortgage advances secured against his property .

In DATE , pursuant to the DATE Act , ORG proposed amendments to the structure plan , to permit a large development ( ORG , henceforth “ the Plan ” ) consisting of CARDINAL , CARDINAL homes , a business park and an international science park . A consortium , ORG , consisting of a number of national and international companies , was formed to develop the Plan . In DATE the Secretary of ORG modified and approved the structure plan . In DATE representatives of ORG and the Consortium met with small land - owners and assured them that their properties would be purchased at full value . The applicant ’s property is situated within the area of the proposed science park and in DATE planning permission was granted to convert it into a hotel .

In DATE the applicant ’s marriage failed . He appointed a firm of chartered surveyors to act on his behalf in negotiations for the sale of his property . On DATE they reported an offer of GBP CARDINAL , which they recommended should be refused since it was some GBP CARDINAL short of the market value at that time .

By DATE the Consortium had acquired PERCENT of the land covered by ORG , which was disclosed on all searches made by potential purchasers , thus putting small home - owners such as the applicant in a weak bargaining position . In DATE the applicant became unemployed and had difficulties in making his mortgage repayments . His attempts to sell PERSON continued to be unsuccessful and by DATE , the chartered surveyors advised that the property was virtually unsaleable . In DATE , the applicant owed the bank in excess of GBP CARDINAL . The property was repossessed and has remained vacant ever since . The bank report that in DATE they received an offer of GBP CARDINAL . The applicant has been advised that , but for the Plan , PERSON ’s market value would be around GBP CARDINAL .

In DATE Professor PERSON advised the applicant that he has no right under ORG DATE , Part VI , to require the local authority to purchase his property since the developers of the proposed science park are private rather than public authorities , and since PERSON has been capable of use as a family home ( “ reasonably beneficial use ” ) throughout the relevant period ( see below ) .
B. Relevant domestic law and practice

Where a proposed development is to be undertaken by a public authority , the “ planning blight ” that ensues may in some circumstances give rise to compensation . Thus ORG DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) , Part VI , LAW , gives an owner a right to require the planning authority to buy his property where , as a result of a planning decision , the land has become “ incapable of reasonably beneficial use ” ( sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .

LAW further provides in Part VI , LAW , that owners have a right to require the planning authority to purchase land affected by “ planning blight ” , namely land “ which may be required for the purposes of the functions of a government department , local authority or statutory undertakers , or of ORG ” or land in an “ action area ” selected by the local authority for comprehensive treatment ( Schedule CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL ) and ( b ) ) .

ORG in his report on the problems of blight caused by LOC ( ORG CARDINAL , DATE ) pointed out that the statutory definition of planning blight is much narrower than the actual problem of blight caused by uncertainty over an area ’s future .
